Description: Upper body fragment, mended from two, of North Ionian black-figured pottery bowl. Three zones of animal friezes preserved, separated by broad bands with added red band lined in white; maeander frieze preserved at top; black-figure decoration in top frieze, confronted boars; in the middle, much of two goats browsing to left; lowest frieze: parts of two goats to right; the filling ornament includes outline rosettes; added red for neck and ribs of the boars in the upper frieze, shoulders and haunches of the goats in the middle frieze. Interior glazed with widely spaced added red bands lined in white.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

School of the Paris Dinos (Kardara pp.217-19) compare Paris E 659 - namepiece of the school - (Kardara p.217 no.1 and pl.12; Samos 6.1, p.144 no.938 and pl.114), London University College (Kardara p.219 no.2 and p.218 fig.188), Oxford G 119.26 (Kardara p.218 no.4 and fig.189; CVA Great Britain 9: pl.4 fig.40), Oxford G 119.27 (Kardara p.219 no.3; CVA Great Britain 9: pl.4 fig.39), and Tübingen 1473 (Kardara, p.217 no.3; Cook GPP pl.31B). Compare also Alexandria 9483.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 14, no. 43 pl. 10)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.151)
